subject: Home Again
event:
I got home a little past midnight on Sunday night, after a long and gruelling trip from Casablanca.  Three flights, changes in NYC/ JFK and Minneapolis/St. Paul, close to twenty-four hours in transit since the wake-up call came through in my Casablance hotel.  I was pretty much a zombie by the time I stumbled off the last flight into Parris's loving arms, and a rotting zombie at that.  After being oh-so-careful in Morocco -- not drinking the water, brushing the teeth with bottle water, avoiding uncooked food, etc -- I made the grievous error of eating at the McDonald's in the Minneapolis airport during our layover there, and came down with an nice all-American case of food poisoning.  By the time I boarded my last flight my stomach felt as if I'd swallowed a lead bowling ball.  It was the first time I'd eaten at a Mickey D's in a decade, and I hope that it's the last.  

Anyway, the last day and a half I've spent mostly in bed or in the john, but I'm feeling a little better now.  This is the first time I've felt strong enough to boot up my computer... where, of course, I found five hundred emails waiting.

The trip was great, and I hope to write more about it later, when I'm feeling stronger.

I have to say, though, I am not sure how many of these overseas trips are left in me.  It's great when I get there, but air travel has just become SO exhausting and SO uncomfortable, especially when oceans are involved, that the mere thought of any more just now is daunting.
Where are the rocket planes that I was promised in the SF of my youth?

comments.upictitle: Sidhe who must be obeyed: pink purple dreads
comments.article: Thank you so much for coming to London, it was lovely to meet you1
Sorry you got so sick, but better home than in a Morocco hotel! Hope you have a quick recovery. (We'll be able to see for ourselves soon: we leave in about two hours for the airport.)

Feel better soon. And the next time you need food in the Minneapolis airport, I recommend French Meadow Bakery & Cafe. I understand they have a real restaurant and a real bakery somewhere in downtown Minneapolis; I have never eaten there. At the airport, they serve a terrific roasted beet salad and perfectly okay soups. We usually eat there when changing planes on our way to Wiscon.
Seconding this.  I spent 4 years traveling back and forth to Minnesota for college and I cannot stress enough how much that place improved my quality of life when it opened.

comments.upictitle: Xray Is As Xray Does: ethelclose
comments.article: I'm so sorry to hear that, George. But like J says -- much better at home than in a Morocco hotel. I am glad to hear that you're home safe. Demand some comfort from the Feline Overlords.

Good luck getting well soon.
Alas... Concorde is taken out of commission. That was close.
Welcome back, George. Sorry about the illness, but it must be very nice to be home so you can recuperate.
Glad you are back home George. Hope you feel better soon.

comments.upictitle: alive isn't sad // it is when it's over: [ASOIAF] Sansa faceless.
comments.article: Welcome back, sir!
Glad you are home. Feel better soon.

George, I'm just as happy you are home to recoup as the next gal...
But lacyintx...That is SUCH a cute pup you have there! What breed(s) is it?
comments.subject: I'm glad too

comments.article: Welcome back.  I look forward to hearing more about the trip and the filming.  And yeah, fast food is a scary proposition.

I could live without the rocket planes myself if it were just easier to get a direct flight to more places. An overseas flight is a pain (I "enjoyed" a 15 hour round trip to Hong Kong in September). But there's nothing worse then surviving one just to sit around another airport (or race through one) just to get back on another plane.

Get better and then let us know how it all went. Sure, I'm impatient to hear all the wonderful details that HBO's lawyers will let you spill :) But your health comes first.
Welcome back, and get better soon! It's cool to know that you had fun - but yeah, bodies are not made for travelling, that's my strong belief after coming back to old Europe from LA XD

Well, call me old-fashioned, but if the air travel takes so much out of you, how about a nice leisurely trans-oceanic cruise? Certainly a lot less stressful than a flight.

As for the the Golden Arches, I have mixed feelings. One can argue the merits of the food all day, but in the end, I am grateful to them for having clean bathrooms and free Wifi while I travelled across Europe.

May you have a speedy recovery!

I'm not sure it was quite food poisoning. The exact same thing happened to me when I ate at McDonald's after having gone a year+ without. I got sick so fast, I don't think it could have been something in the food, but the food itself that had the effect on me. Staph or other viruses take at least a little while, I believe. I got sick immediately, like I was feeling it by the time I finished the meal.

Dunno if that was your experience, but a system that isn't acclimated to McDonald's often can't take it. Same exact thing happened in the documentary "Supersize Me." He vomited up his first McDonald's meal, because he hadn't eaten in ages and was a health nut.

I don't want to sound flippant, but I just want to point out that food-borne infection and food poisoning are not the same: poisoning involves something that is already toxic in the food, one possibility being bacteria that have already multiplied and produced toxins. They can act very fast, as they do not require time to multiply in your system. Usually, if several people ate from the same poisoned food source, many will get sick (while with infection, a single susceptible individual might be sick among many eaters). Alas, you don't get good follow-up of airport commuters.
comments.subject: Food poisoning

comments.article:
The employeers are more than likely all mexicans or cheap help that don't wash hands or handle the food properly or throw old stuff away, nor wash temps. I have had to many friends get food poisoning there. I never eat there.

I was shocked you had stopped in St.Paul MN for a change over. That's the closest you have been to MN in a while since Fargo. I eagerly await the day you do signings in the Twin Cities again.

How bout intant transportation machines or pads. Kind of like Chrichton
s TIMELINE...alas though that was a bad idea...faxing humans...
comments.subject: Feel better, and never eat McD's in MN, I know...

comments.article: Naturally, because ONLY Mexicans are the only people in the world incapable of washing hands or handle food properly.
comments.subject: Re: Feel better, and never eat McD's in MN, I know...

comments.article: Long transit always sucks. The last leg is supposed to bring relief not sickness. I myself have had nothing but bad luck from the Minneapolis airport. Hope you feel batter soon!

That obviously sucks. Kind of funny though. Same thing happened to me, aside from the occasional White Castle and Blimpies(which really shouldn't count)I gave up fast food a decade ago. I also made the mistake of stopping for a quick bite at BK while in transit and soon came to violently regret it. As did everyone in my immediate surrounding for the next day or so, with odd, lingering farts.

I too doubt there was anything wrong with the food other than it being Mc D's and your system not being used to its...nutrional qualities. Hope you feel well enough soon to be able to laugh over it.
Next time youre stuck at the MPLS airport let me know and ill burn ya a steak.. i only live a couple of blocks away:)Hope youre feeling better..and GO Vikes!

Welcome home and feel better, George! I really know what you mean about long plane trips. Next time try to catch a two-segment flight, a trip with two layovers is fatal. It seems we are not exempt from real bad quality food, either. Rest and some good Thanksgiving dinner will cure you.

Sorry to hear that, but good news that you're feeling better.

My grandad keeps saying he's going to give up flying intercontinental (he visits my aunt in Australia once a year) and has been for about twenty years, but usually finds he can do 'one more trip'. Last year he not only flew to Australia but then onto New Zealand and just for good measure flew a Sopworth Camel around an airfield. I think your tolerance to long-distance travel dependson how much fun you're going to have at the other end :-)

We had rocket planes, but the Concorde wasn't quite it. Maybe in a few more years - with luck technology used for the next generation of space shuttle will filter down.

On the plus side, we have "cell phones" that are way more powerful than any computer I would have had even 10 years ago. For stuff like watching your series come to life, it probably would not be too difficult to hire someone to talk with you via a skype connection holding a webcam, and direct them about. Or even with a netbook, so you could have a two-way connection. Where's Waldo, indeed?

Well, good to hear you are home, bad to hear you are not so well. To be honest, I was a little worried, but the worries were eased at the thought that you were probably too busy watching all the games you had Tivo'd while missing, so I did not think too much of it.
Now get well soon, and come back here to tell us all about your joyous adventures in Europe and where else.
Also, if you do not like long haul trips anymore, just take the plane one last time to come to Greece, where a warm room and a loving cat is waiting for you and Parris and all your fluffy animals!! We'd love to have you here, where the climate is so smooth and the sun always shines. I'll even let you sit at my computer to keep updating this blog!!
I want a transporter!

I'm not a fan of it either, which is probably why I can put off getting my US food fix for yet another year.... just to avoid the bleeding plane trip that much longer. Though my 'problem' differs from everyone elses', I admit - the fact that planes now have that extra four inches of leg room or whatever the useless bollocks means that I am absolutely unable to curl up comfortably in a plane seat now to try and sleep the trip through! I end up right atop my poor lengthy little tailbone, and end up in stabbing misery for the entire ride. -__-

As for McDonalds... as someone else said - if you don't eat it, you lose the 'immunity' to it. I totally hope you get to feeling better, though, and manage other trips abroad to this lovely little island. :)

Well, George, I've had full-blown food-poisoning or allergic food reaction and I can tell you, what you experienced probably wasn't quite as severe, more than likely it was your body's natural reaction to the horridly high fat content in that food, the oils, and other poisons that are in most American processed foods, especially a fast-food chain. I'm thankful you're OK! This is just one more reason to never eat at a fast food restaurant again -- if they'd killed off my newest favorite author, I'd have to get in line to sue them!

Before I forget, I've been playing this highly addictive, amazingly well-done new PC RPG from Bioware and it is most definitely inspired by your books. It's called Dragon Age Origins, and if you turn on a TV set for more than an hour, you're probably going to see a commercial for it. In my opinion it is Bioware that should do a full game version of your stories. They are the best at what they do in the industry -- that's why LucasArts is working with them on the huge mass online RPG Star Wars The Old Republic with them -- and they do it right from offices here in Austin, TX, though the main Bioware offices for other productions are up in Edmonton. Just thought I'd fill you in on my impressions.

Have a wonderful holiday, and all I want for Christmas this year or next is another book from you!

John
comments.subject: Happy Thanksgiving!
